newsitem.title: USA: Small banks reject U.S. banking reform compromise.
newsitem.headline: Small banks reject U.S. banking reform compromise.

text.p: Small banks, among the most vocal opponents of allowing banks to combine with commercial companies under U.S. bank reform plans, on Tuesday rejected a compromise on the issue offered by one lawmaker.

Rep Richard Baker, sponsor of a bank reform bill in the House of Representatives, wrote to the Independent Bankers Association of America, the small bank trade group, two weeks ago offering to exempt small banks from a provision allowing mixing of banks and commercial firms.
But the group rejected Baker's deal in a letter dated April 1.
William Sones, the group's president, told the Louisiana Democrat that small banks were not worried about being bought up by bigger commercial companies.
Rather, the small banks worry that they will face unfair competition from huge conglomerates comprising large banks merged with large commercial firms.

"Allowing massive concentration in our economic and financial system would be anticompetitive and would act to the detriment of the American consumer, small business, agriculture and the elderly," Sones wrote.

As congress debates bank reform legislation, most agree that the Depression-era laws separating banking from other financial service industries should be scrapped. But there is little agreement about going further and allowing banks to combine with nonfinancial companies.
Small banks, along with House Banking Committee chairman Jim Leach and other groups, oppose any mixing of banking and commerce.
Rep Baker, along with Senate Banking Committee chairman Alfonse D'Amato, have favored allowing unlimited combinations.

A third approach, contained in a bill sponsored by New Jersey Republican Rep Marge Roukema and Minnesota Democrat Bruce Vento, would place a limit on a bank's permitted non-financial activity. A bank could conduct 25 percent of its business, referred to as a "basket," in nonfinancial activities under the Roukema-Vento bill.

Sones also rejected the basket approach in his letter to Baker. "Even the fallback position of the 25 percent commercial business basket ... would have the same oligopolistic effect over time," he wrote.
Baker had suggested, in a letter to the group's executive vice president Ken Guenther, forbidding banks with less than $500 million in assets from being acquired by a commercial firm.
"Is this 'small bank carve-out' approach one that your members would be able to support?" Baker had asked in his letter.
